docs.abstract: Insect control around world has added 100,000 chemical compounds that could affect health of people and wildlife; persistent organic pollutants, known as POP's, have gone virtually unregulated since they were developed more than 50 years ago; representatives of 121 countries will gather Dec 4-9 in South Africa to complete first international treaty on pesticides and industrial chemicals; negotiators from United States say they expect treaty to be signed and ratified; they say process has been fraught with political and practical challenges because some chemicals are essential to profitable businesses and others are used to control spread of diseases; chart listing 'dirty dozen' pollutants under scrutiny (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: Industrialization and modern insect control have improved the quality of life around the globe, but they have also added some 100,000 chemical compounds that, some scientists worry, could affect the health of people and wildlife. These persistent organic pollutants, known as POP's, have gone virtually unregulated since they were developed more than 50 years ago. But now efforts are being made to control some of them. The final of five meetings to draft a global treaty to restrict production and use of 12 POP's is scheduled for next month in Johannesburg.
